General Information

trans-unit.source: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

seg-source.mrk: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

trans-unit.source: First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

seg-source.mrk: First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.
Fun Facts about Yosemite

trans-unit.source: Yosemite is one of the few places in the U.S. where you can see a rainbow at night.

seg-source.mrk: Yosemite is one of the few places in the U.S. where you can see a rainbow at night.

trans-unit.source: Yosemite is world-famous for its waterfalls and the rainbows that can appear in them. But very few people know about the park’s lunar rainbows or moonbows. In the spring and early summer if the sky is clear and the moon is full, it can produce enough light to create a rainbow from a waterfall’s mist. It’s pure magic.

seg-source.mrk: Yosemite is world-famous for its waterfalls and the rainbows that can appear in them.
But very few people know about the park’s lunar rainbows or moonbows.
In the spring and early summer if the sky is clear and the moon is full, it can produce enough light to create a rainbow from a waterfall’s mist.
It’s pure magic.

trans-unit.source: Yosemite might be our nation’s 3rd national park, but it sparked the idea of national parks.

seg-source.mrk: Yosemite might be our nation’s 3rd national park, but it sparked the idea of national parks.

trans-unit.source: Twenty-six years before it was a national park, President Lincoln signed the Yosemite Land Grant on June 30, 1864, protecting the Mariposa Grove and Yosemite Valley. It was the first time the government protected land because of its natural beauty so that people could enjoy it, and we’re still benefiting from their foresight today. Thanks to John Muir’s passionate writing to further protect the delicate ecosystem of the High Sierra, Yosemite later became a national park..

seg-source.mrk: Twenty-six years before it was a national park, President Lincoln signed the Yosemite Land Grant on June 30, 1864, protecting the Mariposa Grove and Yosemite Valley.
It was the first time the government protected land because of its natural beauty so that people could enjoy it, and we’re still benefiting from their foresight today.
Thanks to John Muir’s passionate writing to further protect the delicate ecosystem of the High Sierra, Yosemite later became a national park..

trans-unit.source: Yosemite’s granite rock formations glow like fire at sunset.

seg-source.mrk: Yosemite’s granite rock formations glow like fire at sunset.

trans-unit.source: Sunlight plays amazing tricks at Yosemite -- illuminating El Capitan and Half Dome in brilliant reds and oranges. Horsetail Fall is famous for appearing to be on fire when it reflects the orange glow of sunset in mid- to late-February. It’s a spectacular sight reminiscent of Yosemite’s historic Firefall, which occurred nightly until 1968, when hotel operators would push campfire embers over Glacier Point to wow park goers.

seg-source.mrk: Sunlight plays amazing tricks at Yosemite -- illuminating El Capitan and Half Dome in brilliant reds and oranges.
Horsetail Fall is famous for appearing to be on fire when it reflects the orange glow of sunset in mid- to late-February.
It’s a spectacular sight reminiscent of Yosemite’s historic Firefall, which occurred nightly until 1968, when hotel operators would push campfire embers over Glacier Point to wow park goers.

trans-unit.source: Yosemite is home to one of the tallest waterfalls in the world.

seg-source.mrk: Yosemite is home to one of the tallest waterfalls in the world.

trans-unit.source: At 2,425 feet, Yosemite Falls is one of tallest on the planet, but did you know, it’s actually made up of three separate falls? Upper Yosemite Fall, the middle cascades and Lower Yosemite Fall makeup Yosemite Falls, which can be seen from numerous places around Yosemite Valley. Learn more about the other waterfalls at Yosemite.

Upper Yosemite Fall, the middle cascades and Lower Yosemite Fall makeup Yosemite Falls, which can be seen from numerous places around Yosemite Valley.
